refnamediv.refpurpose: A tree-like data structure that can be used with the GtkTreeView

refsynopsisdiv.title: Synopsis

refsect1.title: Implemented Interfaces
refsect1.para: GtkTreeStore implements GtkBuildable, GtkTreeDragDest, GtkTreeModel, GtkTreeDragSource and GtkTreeSortable.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The GtkTreeStore object is a list model for use with a GtkTreeView widget. It implements the GtkTreeModel interface, and consequentialy, can use all of the methods available there. It also implements the GtkTreeSortable interface so it can be sorted by the view. Finally, it also implements the tree drag and drop interfaces.

refsect2.title: GtkTreeStore as GtkBuildable
refsect2.para: The GtkTreeStore implementation of the GtkBuildable interface allows to specify the model columns with a <columns> element that may contain multiple <column> elements, each specifying one model column. The "type" attribute specifies the data type for the column.

example.title: A UI Definition fragment for a tree store

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_new ()
refsect2.para: Creates a new tree store as with n_columns columns each of the types passed in. Note that only types derived from standard GObject fundamental types are supported.
As an example, gtk_tree_store_new (3, G_TYPE_INT, G_TYPE_STRING, GDK_TYPE_PIXBUF); will create a new GtkTreeStore with three columns, of type int, string and GdkPixbuf respectively.

listitem.simpara: number of columns in the tree store
all GType types for the columns, from first to last

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_newv ()
refsect2.para: Non vararg creation function. Used primarily by language bindings.

listitem.simpara: number of columns in the tree store
an array of GType types for the columns, from first to last

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_set_column_types ()
refsect2.para: This function is meant primarily for GObjects that inherit from GtkTreeStore, and should only be used when constructing a new GtkTreeStore. It will not function after a row has been added, or a method on the GtkTreeModel interface is called.

listitem.simpara: Number of columns for the tree store
An array of GType types, one for each column

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_set_value ()
refsect2.programlisting: void gtk_tree_store_set_value (GtkTreeStore *tree_store, GtkTreeIter *iter, gint column, GValue *value);
refsect2.para: Sets the data in the cell specified by iter and column. The type of value must be convertible to the type of the column.

listitem.simpara: A valid GtkTreeIter for the row being modified

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_set ()
refsect2.para: Sets the value of one or more cells in the row referenced by iter. The variable argument list should contain integer column numbers, each column number followed by the value to be set. The list is terminated by a -1. For example, to set column 0 with type G_TYPE_STRING to "Foo", you would write gtk_tree_store_set (store, iter, 0, "Foo", -1). The value will be copied or referenced by the store if appropriate.

listitem.simpara: A valid GtkTreeIter for the row being modified
pairs of column number and value, terminated with -1

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_set_valist ()
refsect2.para: See gtk_tree_store_set(); this version takes a va_list for use by language bindings.

listitem.simpara: A valid GtkTreeIter for the row being modified

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_set_valuesv ()
refsect2.programlisting: void gtk_tree_store_set_valuesv (GtkTreeStore *tree_store, GtkTreeIter *iter, gint *columns, GValue *values, gint n_values);
refsect2.para: A variant of gtk_tree_store_set_valist() which takes the columns and values as two arrays, instead of varargs. This function is mainly intended for language bindings or in case the number of columns to change is not known until run-time.

listitem.simpara: A valid GtkTreeIter for the row being modified
the length of the columns and values arrays

refsect2.para: Since 2.12

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_remove ()
refsect2.para: Removes iter from tree_store. After being removed, iter is set to the next valid row at that level, or invalidated if it previously pointed to the last one.

listitem.simpara: TRUE if iter is still valid, FALSE if not.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_insert ()
refsect2.programlisting: void gtk_tree_store_insert (GtkTreeStore *tree_store, GtkTreeIter *iter, GtkTreeIter *parent, gint position);
refsect2.para: Creates a new row at position. If parent is non-NULL, then the row will be made a child of parent. Otherwise, the row will be created at the toplevel. If position is larger than the number of rows at that level, then the new row will be inserted to the end of the list. iter will be changed to point to this new row. The row will be empty after this function is called. To fill in values, you need to call gtk_tree_store_set() or gtk_tree_store_set_value().

listitem.simpara: An unset GtkTreeIter to set to the new row
position to insert the new row

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_insert_before ()
refsect2.para: Inserts a new row before sibling. If sibling is NULL, then the row will be appended to parent 's children. If parent and sibling are NULL, then the row will be appended to the toplevel. If both sibling and parent are set, then parent must be the parent of sibling. When sibling is set, parent is optional.
iter will be changed to point to this new row. The row will be empty after this function is called. To fill in values, you need to call gtk_tree_store_set() or gtk_tree_store_set_value().

listitem.simpara: An unset GtkTreeIter to set to the new row

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_insert_after ()
refsect2.para: Inserts a new row after sibling. If sibling is NULL, then the row will be prepended to parent 's children. If parent and sibling are NULL, then the row will be prepended to the toplevel. If both sibling and parent are set, then parent must be the parent of sibling. When sibling is set, parent is optional.
iter will be changed to point to this new row. The row will be empty after this function is called. To fill in values, you need to call gtk_tree_store_set() or gtk_tree_store_set_value().

listitem.simpara: An unset GtkTreeIter to set to the new row

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_insert_with_values ()
refsect2.programlisting: void gtk_tree_store_insert_with_values (GtkTreeStore *tree_store, GtkTreeIter *iter, GtkTreeIter *parent, gint position, ...);
refsect2.para: Creates a new row at position. iter will be changed to point to this new row. If position is larger than the number of rows on the list, then the new row will be appended to the list. The row will be filled with the values given to this function.

listitem.simpara: An unset GtkTreeIter to set the new row, or NULL.
position to insert the new row
pairs of column number and value, terminated with -1

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_insert_with_valuesv ()
refsect2.programlisting: void gtk_tree_store_insert_with_valuesv (GtkTreeStore *tree_store, GtkTreeIter *iter, GtkTreeIter *parent, gint position, gint *columns, GValue *values, gint n_values);
refsect2.para: A variant of gtk_tree_store_insert_with_values() which takes the columns and values as two arrays, instead of varargs. This function is mainly intended for language bindings.

listitem.simpara: An unset GtkTreeIter to set the new row, or NULL.
position to insert the new row
the length of the columns and values arrays

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_prepend ()
refsect2.para: Prepends a new row to tree_store. If parent is non-NULL, then it will prepend the new row before the first child of parent, otherwise it will prepend a row to the top level. iter will be changed to point to this new row. The row will be empty after this function is called. To fill in values, you need to call gtk_tree_store_set() or gtk_tree_store_set_value().

listitem.simpara: An unset GtkTreeIter to set to the prepended row

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_append ()
refsect2.para: Appends a new row to tree_store. If parent is non-NULL, then it will append the new row after the last child of parent, otherwise it will append a row to the top level. iter will be changed to point to this new row. The row will be empty after this function is called. To fill in values, you need to call gtk_tree_store_set() or gtk_tree_store_set_value().

listitem.simpara: An unset GtkTreeIter to set to the appended row

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_is_ancestor ()
refsect2.para: Returns TRUE if iter is an ancestor of descendant. That is, iter is the parent (or grandparent or great-grandparent) of descendant.

listitem.simpara: TRUE, if iter is an ancestor of descendant

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_iter_depth ()
refsect2.para: Returns the depth of iter. This will be 0 for anything on the root level, 1 for anything down a level, etc.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_clear ()
refsect2.para: Removes all rows from tree_store

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_iter_is_valid ()
refsect2.para: WARNING: This function is slow. Only use it for debugging and/or testing purposes.
Checks if the given iter is a valid iter for this GtkTreeStore.

listitem.simpara: TRUE if the iter is valid, FALSE if the iter is invalid.

refsect2.para: Since 2.2

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_reorder ()
refsect2.para: Reorders the children of parent in tree_store to follow the order indicated by new_order. Note that this function only works with unsorted stores.

listitem.simpara: an array of integers mapping the new position of each child to its old position before the re-ordering, i.e. new_order[newpos] = oldpos.

refsect2.para: Since 2.2

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_swap ()
refsect2.para: Swaps a and b in the same level of tree_store. Note that this function only works with unsorted stores.
Since 2.2

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_move_before ()
refsect2.para: Moves iter in tree_store to the position before position. iter and position should be in the same level. Note that this function only works with unsorted stores. If position is NULL, iter will be moved to the end of the level.
Since 2.2

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_store_move_after ()
refsect2.para: Moves iter in tree_store to the position after position. iter and position should be in the same level. Note that this function only works with unsorted stores. If position is NULL, iter will be moved to the start of the level.
Since 2.2
